pageProps.contentHtml:
Harnack's inequality, subharmonic functions

Let {fn}n\set{f_n}_n{fn​}n​ be a sequence of holomorphic functions on D\DD with the property that

F(z)=∑n=1∞∣fn(z)∣2≤1F\p{z} = \sum_{n=1}^\infty \abs{f_n\p{z}}^2 \leq 1F(z)=n=1∑∞​∣fn​(z)∣2≤1

for all z∈Dz \in \Dz∈D. Show that the series defining F(z)F\p{z}F(z) converges uniformly on compact subsets of D\DD and that FFF is subharmonic.
Solution.

Given B(z,r)⊆DB\p{z, r} \subseteq \DB(z,r)⊆D, we have by Cauchy-Schwarz

∣fn(z)∣2=∣12π∫02πfn(z+reiθ) dθ∣2≤14π2(∫02π∣fn(z+reiθ)∣2 dθ)(∫02π dθ)=12π∫02π∣fn(z+reiθ)∣2 dθ,\begin{aligned} \abs{f_n\p{z}}^2 &= \abs{\frac{1}{2\pi} \int_0^{2\pi} f_n\p{z + re^{i\theta}} \,\diff\theta}^2 \\ &\leq \frac{1}{4\pi^2} \p{\int_0^{2\pi} \abs{f_n\p{z + re^{i\theta}}}^2 \,\diff\theta} \p{\int_0^{2\pi} \,\diff\theta} \\ &= \frac{1}{2\pi} \int_0^{2\pi} \abs{f_n\p{z + re^{i\theta}}}^2 \,\diff\theta, \end{aligned}∣fn​(z)∣2​=∣∣​2π1​∫02π​fn​(z+reiθ)dθ∣∣​2≤4π21​(∫02π​∣∣​fn​(z+reiθ)∣∣​2dθ)(∫02π​dθ)=2π1​∫02π​∣∣​fn​(z+reiθ)∣∣​2dθ,​

so ∣fn∣2\abs{f_n}^2∣fn​∣2 satisfies the sub-mean value property. Since ∣fn∣2\abs{f_n}^2∣fn​∣2 is continuous (fnf_nfn​ is holomorphic), it follows that ∣fn∣2\abs{f_n}^2∣fn​∣2 is subharmonic. Thus, FFF is the pointwise supremum of a family of subharmonic functions, so it is itself subharmonic.

It remains to show locally uniformly convergence. First, we will show that if uuu is a continuous subharmonic function, then it satisfies a sub-Poisson representation formula on closed disks. Indeed, let B(z0,r)‾⊆D\cl{B\p{z_0, r}} \subseteq \DB(z0​,r)​⊆D and vvv be the solution to the Dirichlet problem on B(z0,r)B\p{z_0, r}B(z0​,r) with boundary condition uuu so that

v(z)≤u(z)=12π∫02πRe⁡(reiθ+z−z0reiθ−(z−z0))v(z0+reiθ) dθv\p{z} \leq u\p{z} = \frac{1}{2\pi} \int_0^{2\pi} \Re\p{\frac{re^{i\theta} + z - z_0}{re^{i\theta} - \p{z - z_0}}} v\p{z_0 + re^{i\theta}} \,\diff\thetav(z)≤u(z)=2π1​∫02π​Re(reiθ−(z−z0​)reiθ+z−z0​​)v(z0​+reiθ)dθ

on ∂B(z0,r)\partial B\p{z_0, r}∂B(z0​,r). By subharmonicity, this implies that v(z)≤u(z)v\p{z} \leq u\p{z}v(z)≤u(z) on all of B(z0,r)B\p{z_0, r}B(z0​,r), so we get the sub-Poisson representation formula.

Let K=B(0,R)‾K = \cl{B\p{0, R}}K=B(0,R)​ for 0<R<10 < R < 10<R<1 so that B(0,1+R2)‾⊆D\cl{B\p{0, \frac{1 + R}{2}}} \subseteq \DB(0,21+R​)​⊆D as well. Let R′=1+R2R' = \frac{1 + R}{2}R′=21+R​. Then if z∈Kz \in Kz∈K,

v(z)≤12π∫02πRe⁡(R′eiθ+zR′eiθ−z)v(R′eiθ) dθ=12π∫02πR′−∣z∣2∣R′eiθ−z∣2v(R′eiθ) dθ≤12π∫02π(R′)2−R(R′−R)2v(R′eiθ) dθ≤R′+RR′−Rv(0)≕MKv(0).\begin{aligned} v\p{z} &\leq \frac{1}{2\pi} \int_0^{2\pi} \Re\p{\frac{R'e^{i\theta} + z}{R'e^{i\theta} - z}} v\p{R'e^{i\theta}} \,\diff\theta \\ &= \frac{1}{2\pi} \int_0^{2\pi} \frac{R' - \abs{z}^2}{\abs{R'e^{i\theta} - z}^2} v\p{R'e^{i\theta}} \,\diff\theta \\ &\leq \frac{1}{2\pi} \int_0^{2\pi} \frac{\p{R'}^2 - R}{\p{R' - R}^2} v\p{R'e^{i\theta}} \,\diff\theta \\ &\leq \frac{R' + R}{R' - R} v\p{0} \\ &\eqqcolon M_K v\p{0}. \end{aligned}v(z)​≤2π1​∫02π​Re(R′eiθ−zR′eiθ+z​)v(R′eiθ)dθ=2π1​∫02π​∣R′eiθ−z∣2R′−∣z∣2​v(R′eiθ)dθ≤2π1​∫02π​(R′−R)2(R′)2−R​v(R′eiθ)dθ≤R′−RR′+R​v(0)=:MK​v(0).​

for any non-negative subharmonic vvv. If we let FN=∑n=1N∣fn∣2F_N = \sum_{n=1}^N \abs{f_n}^2FN​=∑n=1N​∣fn​∣2, then FNF_NFN​ is subharmonic as a sum of subharmonic functions. Thus, for N≤MN \leq MN≤M,

∣FM(z)−FN(z)∣≤MK∣FM(0)−FN(0)∣,\abs{F_M\p{z} - F_N\p{z}} \leq M_K \abs{F_M\p{0} - F_N\p{0}},∣FM​(z)−FN​(z)∣≤MK​∣FM​(0)−FN​(0)∣,

so {FN}n\set{F_N}_n{FN​}n​ is uniformly Cauchy on KKK, since the partial sums is Cauchy at 000. Hence, FFF converges locally uniformly, as required.
